(3) Developer mode: enables advanced features like USB debugging. Should be disabled on production/corporate devices as it allows direct system access. (4) Application spoofing: fake apps that mimic legitimate ones to steal credentials. Check developer name, reviews, download count before installing. (5) Symptoms of compromised device: unexplained high data usage (malware exfiltrating data), excessive ads (adware), fake security warnings ('Your device is infected! Click here'), degraded performance (cryptominer or malware consuming resources), unexpected app behavior (legitimate apps modified by malware). (6) High network traffic: use data usage settings to identify which app is consuming bandwidth. Unknown apps using lots of data = likely malware. (7) Leaked personal data: indicates a compromised app or device. Change all passwords, remove suspicious apps, consider factory reset. (8) Response to suspected compromise: disconnect from network, identify malicious apps, remove them, change passwords, scan with mobile security software, factory reset if necessary.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, troubleshoot common PC security issues.
subtopics: Common symptoms (Unable to access network, Desktop alerts, False antivirus alerts, Altered files Missing/renamed/Inaccessible, Unwanted OS notifications, OS update failures)
Browser symptoms (Random pop-ups, Certificate warnings, Redirection, Degraded performance)
objectives.studyNotes: PC security symptoms help identify the type of attack. Key exam tips: (1) Unable to access network: could be malware modifying host file, DNS settings, or firewall rules. Check hosts file (C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts) for unauthorized entries. Check DNS settings for unauthorized DNS servers. (2) False antivirus alerts (scareware): pop-ups claiming your system is infected, urging you to download 'antivirus' software (which is actually malware). Legitimate antivirus does not use browser pop-ups. (3) Altered/missing/renamed files: possible ransomware (encrypted files with changed extensions), or malware deleting/hiding files. If files have strange extensions (.encrypted, .locked), ransomware is likely. (4) Desktop alerts/unwanted notifications: could be adware or browser notification permissions granted to malicious sites. Revoke notification permissions in browser settings. (5) OS update failures: malware may block updates to prevent patches that would detect/remove it. Try running updates in Safe Mode. (6) Browser redirection: DNS hijacking, modified proxy settings, or browser hijacker malware. Check proxy settings, DNS configuration, and browser extensions. (7) Certificate warnings: could indicate man-in-the-middle attack, expired certificate, or compromised website. Do NOT proceed to sites with certificate warnings unless you understand the cause. (8) Random pop-ups: adware or browser hijacker. Remove suspicious extensions, run anti-malware scan, reset browser settings. (9) Degraded browser performance: too many extensions, malicious extensions running in background, or cryptominer scripts.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, implement best practices associated with documentation and support systems information management.
subtopics: Ticketing systems (User info, Device info, Description, Categories, Severity, Escalation, Clear written communication Issue/Progress/Resolution)
Asset management (Inventory lists, CMDB, Asset tags, Procurement lifecycle, Warranty/licensing, Assigned users)
Types of documents (Incident reports, SOPs Software installation procedure, New user/onboarding checklist, Off-boarding checklist, SLAs Internal/External, Knowledge base/articles)
objectives.studyNotes: Documentation and ticketing are fundamental IT skills. Key exam tips: (1) Ticketing best practices: document EVERYTHING. Each ticket should include: user info (name, contact, location), device info (asset tag, model, OS), detailed problem description, category and severity, all troubleshooting steps taken, resolution, and time spent. (2) Severity levels: Critical (system down, affecting many users), High (major functionality impaired), Medium (workaround available), Low (minor issue, cosmetic). Escalation path follows severity. (3) CMDB (Configuration Management Database): tracks all IT assets and their relationships. Central source of truth for the IT environment. (4) Asset tags: unique identifiers physically attached to equipment. Link physical device to CMDB record. (5) Procurement lifecycle: request > approve > purchase > receive > deploy > maintain > retire/dispose. (6) SLAs (Service Level Agreements): define expected service levels. Internal = between IT and other departments. External = between company and vendor/customer. Include response times, resolution times, uptime percentages. (7) Knowledge base: searchable collection of known issues and solutions. Reduces repeat troubleshooting time. (8) Off-boarding checklist: disable accounts, recover equipment, revoke access, transfer data, remove from groups. Critical for security. (9) Common pitfall: never close a ticket without documenting the resolution -- this builds the knowledge base and helps track trends.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, apply change management procedures.
subtopics: Documented business processes (Rollback plan, Backup plan, Sandbox testing, Responsible staff, Scope, Change type Standard/Normal/Emergency, Date/time Change freeze/Maintenance windows, Affected systems/impact)
Change management (Request forms, Purpose, Risk analysis/level, Change board approvals, Implementation, Peer review, End-user acceptance)
objectives.studyNotes: Change management prevents uncontrolled changes from causing outages. Key exam tips: (1) Change types: Standard = pre-approved, low-risk, routine (e.g., password reset). Normal = requires full change management process and approval. Emergency = urgent, bypasses some process but still requires documentation after the fact. (2) Every change needs: a rollback plan (how to undo if something goes wrong), a backup plan (protect current state), sandbox/test environment validation, identified responsible staff, defined scope, risk analysis, scheduled maintenance window, and list of affected systems. (3) Change freeze: period when no changes are allowed (e.g., holiday shopping season for retail). Only emergency changes may be permitted during a freeze. (4) Change Advisory Board (CAB): reviews and approves/denies change requests. Includes stakeholders from affected areas. (5) Process flow: Submit request > Risk analysis > CAB review/approval > Schedule in maintenance window > Implement change > Peer review > End-user acceptance testing > Document results. (6) If change fails: execute the rollback plan and document what happened. Do NOT continue with a failing change. (7) Common pitfall: emergency changes still need documentation -- do it after the fact. 'We had to act fast' is not an excuse for zero documentation.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, implement workstation backup and recovery methods.
subtopics: Backup rotation schemes (Onsite vs offsite, GFS, 3-2-1 rule)
objectives.studyNotes: Backup types and strategies are GUARANTEED exam topics. Memorize: (1) Full backup: copies ALL data every time. Slowest backup, fastest restore. Uses the most storage. (2) Incremental backup: copies only data changed since the LAST BACKUP (full or incremental). Fastest backup, slowest restore (need full + all incrementals). (3) Differential backup: copies all data changed since the LAST FULL BACKUP. Middle ground -- backup grows each day, but restore only needs full + latest differential. (4) Synthetic full: creates a full backup by combining the previous full with subsequent incrementals, without reading from source again. Reduces backup window. (5) Memory aid: 'Incremental = since last anything, Differential = since last Full'. (6) 3-2-1 Rule: 3 copies of data, on 2 different types of media, with 1 copy offsite. This is the gold standard for data protection. (7) GFS (Grandfather-Father-Son): rotation scheme. Daily (Son), Weekly (Father), Monthly (Grandfather). Provides multiple recovery points at different intervals. (8) Backup testing: CRITICAL. Untested backups may be useless. Regularly test restores to verify data integrity. Schedule tests monthly or quarterly at minimum. (9) Onsite backup: fast access for quick recovery. Offsite backup: protection against physical disasters (fire, flood). Cloud backup qualifies as offsite. (10) In-place recovery overwrites current data with backup. Alternative location restores to a different path (useful for comparing or recovering specific files).

objectives.title: Given a scenario, use common safety procedures.
subtopics: Personal safety (Disconnect power, Lifting techniques, Fire safety, Safety goggles, Air filter mask)
objectives.studyNotes: Safety procedures protect both people and equipment. Key exam tips: (1) ESD (Electrostatic Discharge): as little as 30V can damage components (humans cannot feel less than 3000V). Always use ESD wrist strap connected to chassis ground or ESD mat when handling internal components. (2) Never work on equipment while wearing synthetic clothing or on carpet without ESD protection. (3) Antistatic bags: store and transport components in antistatic bags. The bag exterior is conductive -- never place components ON a bag (only IN it). (4) Proper lifting: bend at knees, keep back straight, hold close to body. Get help for heavy equipment (servers, UPS). Never lift with your back. (5) Electrical safety: always disconnect power before opening equipment. Never work on equipment plugged in. Ensure equipment is properly grounded (three-prong plugs). (6) Fire safety: know fire extinguisher types. Class C (electrical fires) -- use CO2 or dry chemical, NEVER water. ABC extinguisher covers most scenarios. (7) Safety goggles: when working with toner (fine particles), compressed air cleaning, or any operation producing debris. (8) Air filter mask: when working in dusty environments, cleaning equipment, or handling toner. Toner particles are very fine and harmful to inhale. (9) Cable management: prevents tripping hazards, improves airflow, simplifies troubleshooting. Label everything. (10) Government regulations: OSHA (workplace safety), EPA (environmental disposal), local building codes for electrical work.

objectives.title: Summarize environmental impacts and local environment controls.
subtopics: MSDS documentation (Battery disposal, Toner disposal, Other device disposal)
objectives.studyNotes: Environmental controls protect equipment and comply with regulations. Key exam tips: (1) MSDS/SDS (Material Safety Data Sheet/Safety Data Sheet): documents chemical properties, hazards, and disposal procedures for materials. Required for toner, batteries, cleaning chemicals. Must be available to all employees who handle these materials. (2) Battery disposal: never throw in regular trash. Lithium batteries can catch fire. Use certified recyclers. Swollen batteries are hazardous -- handle carefully. (3) Toner disposal: fine powder, harmful if inhaled. Return to manufacturer for recycling or use certified disposal. Clean spills with a toner-specific vacuum (regular vacuums spread fine particles). (4) UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply): provides battery backup during power outages. Allows graceful shutdown of systems. Also conditions power (removes surges/sags). Two main types: online (continuous battery power) and line-interactive (switches to battery when needed). (5) Surge suppressor: protects against voltage spikes. Measured in joules -- higher is better. Replace after a major surge (they degrade). NOT the same as a UPS (no battery backup). (6) Brownout: reduced voltage. Can damage equipment. UPS protects against this. (7) Blackout: complete power loss. UPS provides temporary power. (8) Temperature: ideal server room is 68-72F (20-22C). Overheating causes failures. Use hot aisle/cold aisle configuration in data centers. (9) Humidity: too high = condensation/corrosion. Too low = ESD risk. Ideal: 40-60%. (10) Dust cleanup: use compressed air (hold can upright to avoid liquid). Never use regular vacuums near electronics -- use ESD-safe vacuums.

objectives.title: Explain the importance of prohibited content/activity and privacy, licensing, and policy concepts.
subtopics: Incident response (Chain of custody, Inform management/law enforcement, Drive copy, Documentation, Order of volatility)
Licensing/DRM/EULA (Valid licenses, Perpetual, Personal vs corporate, Open-source)
Regulated data (Credit card, Government ID, PII, Healthcare, Data retention)
objectives.studyNotes: Policy, compliance, and incident response are essential knowledge. Key exam tips: (1) Chain of custody: documents who handled evidence, when, and what was done. Must be unbroken for evidence to be admissible. Every transfer is documented with signatures, dates, and times. (2) Order of volatility (most to least volatile): CPU registers/cache > RAM > Swap file > HDD/SSD > Removable media > Printouts. Capture the most volatile data FIRST because it disappears when power is lost. (3) Drive copy for forensics: create a bit-for-bit image using write-blocker. NEVER work on the original drive. Document hash values to prove evidence was not altered. (4) Licensing types: Perpetual = one-time purchase, use forever. Subscription = pay periodically, lose access when payments stop. Open-source = free to use/modify (but check specific license terms like GPL, MIT, Apache). (5) EULA (End User License Agreement): legal contract between user and software publisher. Violating EULA can have legal consequences. (6) PII (Personally Identifiable Information): any data that can identify an individual (name, SSN, address, email, phone). Must be protected per regulations. (7) Regulated data: PCI DSS (credit cards), HIPAA (healthcare), FERPA (education), GDPR (EU personal data). Non-compliance = fines and legal liability. (8) NDA (Non-Disclosure Agreement): prevents sharing confidential information. MNDA = Mutual NDA (both parties). (9) AUP (Acceptable Use Policy): defines what users may/may not do with company resources. (10) Data retention policies: define how long data must be kept and when it must be destroyed.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, use proper communication techniques and professionalism.
subtopics: Deal with difficult customers (Don't argue, Don't dismiss, Don't be judgmental, Clarify/restate)
objectives.studyNotes: Soft skills and professionalism questions appear on every exam. Key exam tips: (1) Active listening: let the user explain without interrupting. Take notes. Repeat back what you heard to confirm understanding ('So what you are saying is...'). (2) Avoid jargon: explain technical concepts in simple terms the user can understand. Saying 'your DNS cache needs flushing' means nothing to most users -- say 'I need to refresh your computer's internet address book.' (3) Dealing with difficult customers: NEVER argue, dismiss concerns, or be judgmental. Stay calm, empathize, and focus on solving the problem. If the customer is wrong, gently redirect without saying 'you are wrong.' (4) Set expectations: always give a realistic timeline. Under-promise and over-deliver. If you cannot fix it today, say so. (5) Documentation: document every interaction, what was tried, and the outcome. This protects you and helps future technicians. (6) Follow up: after resolving an issue, follow up to ensure the user is satisfied and the problem has not returned. This builds trust and catches recurring issues. (7) Confidentiality: never discuss a customer's issues with others. Handle sensitive data (passwords, personal info) with care. (8) Cultural sensitivity: be respectful of different backgrounds, customs, and communication styles. (9) Common pitfall: do NOT check your phone during a customer interaction. Avoid all distractions. Give the user your full attention.

objectives.title: Explain the basics of scripting.
subtopics: Use cases (Basic automation, Restarting machines, Remapping drives, Installing apps, Automated backups, Gathering info, Initiating updates)
Other considerations (Introducing malware, Changing settings, Browser/system crashes)
objectives.studyNotes: Scripting basics focus on file types and use cases, not writing code. Key exam tips: (1) Script file types: .bat = Windows batch file (CMD commands). .ps1 = PowerShell script (most powerful Windows scripting). .vbs = VBScript (legacy Windows scripting). .sh = Bash/shell script (Linux/macOS). .js = JavaScript (web/Node.js). .py = Python (cross-platform, very popular). (2) Common use cases: automate repetitive tasks (user account creation, software deployment), scheduled backups, drive mapping at login, gathering system information for inventory, pushing updates across multiple machines. (3) Security risks: scripts can be used maliciously. A malicious .bat or .ps1 file can delete files, install malware, change settings, exfiltrate data. Never run scripts from untrusted sources. (4) PowerShell execution policy: by default, PowerShell restricts running scripts. Policies: Restricted (no scripts), AllSigned (only signed scripts), RemoteSigned (local scripts run freely, downloaded must be signed), Unrestricted (all scripts run). (5) Scripts can cause unintended damage: an incorrect deletion script can wipe important data. Always test in a sandbox first. (6) Environment variables: scripts often use these to reference system paths (e.g., %USERPROFILE% in Windows, $HOME in Linux). (7) Common pitfall: do NOT memorize script syntax -- the exam tests understanding of what scripts do and when to use them, not how to write code.

objectives.title: Given a scenario, use remote access technologies.
subtopics: Methods/tools (RDP, VPN, VNC, SSH, RMM, SPICE, WinRM, Third-party Screen sharing/Videoconferencing/File transfer/Desktop management)
objectives.studyNotes: Remote access is essential for modern IT support. Key exam tips: (1) RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol): Microsoft, port 3389. Provides full graphical desktop access. Windows Pro/Enterprise only as host. Encrypted. (2) VPN (Virtual Private Network): creates encrypted tunnel to corporate network. Provides access to internal resources as if on-site. (3) VNC (Virtual Network Computing): platform-independent remote desktop. Port 5900. Less secure than RDP by default -- use with VPN. (4) SSH (Secure Shell): encrypted command-line remote access. Port 22. Used for Linux/macOS/network device administration. Replaces insecure Telnet. (5) RMM (Remote Monitoring and Management): enterprise tools for managing many endpoints remotely (ConnectWise, Datto, NinjaRMM). Includes monitoring, patching, remote access. (6) SPICE: remote display protocol for virtual machines (common in KVM/QEMU environments). (7) WinRM (Windows Remote Management): Microsoft's implementation of WS-Management protocol. Enables remote PowerShell commands. Used in enterprise automation. (8) Third-party tools: TeamViewer, AnyDesk (desktop management), Zoom/Teams (screen sharing/video), secure file transfer tools. (9) Security considerations: always use encryption, use MFA for remote access, restrict access by IP/user, keep remote access software updated, monitor remote sessions, disable remote access when not needed. (10) Common pitfall: RDP exposed directly to the internet is a major security risk. Always use VPN first, then RDP through the VPN tunnel.

objectives.title: Explain basic concepts related to artificial intelligence (AI).
subtopics: Private vs public (Data security, Data source, Data privacy)
objectives.studyNotes: AI concepts are new to the A+ exam and reflect current technology trends. Key exam tips: (1) Application integration: AI is embedded in many tools -- email (smart compose), search (intelligent results), security (threat detection), help desks (chatbots), document analysis, and code assistance. Understand that AI augments existing workflows. (2) Appropriate use policy: organizations should have clear policies on when and how AI tools can be used. Consider data sensitivity, output verification, and acceptable use cases. (3) Plagiarism: AI-generated content may not be original. Using AI output without attribution may violate academic or professional integrity policies. Content generated by AI may also inadvertently reproduce copyrighted material. (4) Limitations -- Bias: AI models can reflect biases in their training data, leading to unfair or skewed outputs. Hallucinations: AI can generate plausible-sounding but factually incorrect information. Accuracy: AI output should always be verified by a human, especially for critical decisions. (5) Private vs public AI: Public AI (ChatGPT, Gemini) may use your input for training -- do NOT enter sensitive/confidential data. Private/enterprise AI keeps data within the organization's control. (6) Data security: sensitive company data entered into public AI tools may be exposed. Establish clear data classification policies for AI use. (7) Common pitfall: do NOT blindly trust AI output. Always verify critical information from authoritative sources.
